interfaces.name: Picimo.App
interfaces.description:
Bootstrapping for *picimo* applications.

You instantiate a *picimo* application by explicitly creating a `new Picimo.App` instance.

attributes.description: The number of seconds from application start.

attributes.name: frameNo
attributes.description: The current frame number.

attributes.name: assetBaseUrl
attributes.description:
The base url for all assets. *Maybe* be undefined. The base url can be set via the __assetBaseUrl__
*option* or via the global var `PICIMO_ASSET_BASE_URL` (will override the option).
If unspecified the base url will be calculated from `locaation.href`

attributes.name: height

events.name: init
events.description: Will be called right after app creation time.

events.name: frame
events.description:
On frame event. The renderer has been initialized,
but this is before the scene graph is rendered.

events.name: renderFrame
events.description:
On frame event. The renderer has been initialized
and the scene graph is executed but the renderer is not yet finished,
so this is the last call to create render commands if wanted.

enums.name: Picimo.enum.ObjectFit
enums.description_after_idl:
![The Object Fit Property](/assets/images/doc/displaySize.png)

The object fit describes how an object size is computed in relation to its container area.

- **contain** will always show the whole object but may not fill up the whole area.
- **cover** will always fill the whole area, but the object may be cropped.

Both strategies will preserve the object size ratio.

Die render priority bestimmt die Reihenfolge in der die Nodes
mittels `renderFrame()` aufgerufen werden.

attributes.description: Accepts a boolean value or a function. When the ready function returns a *truthy* value then this is node is *ready*.

When set to `false` the node will not be displayed. The *frame*, *renderFrame* and *frameEnd* events will not be called.
BUT `init` and `initGl` will be called. If you don't want to initialize the node set the *ready* attribute to `false`.

interfaces.name: Picimo.graph.SpriteGroup
interfaces.description:
A sprite group renders a group of sprites to the scene.
All vertex data will be will be uploaded to the GPU *every frame*.
So that's why you should choose the capacity carefully.

You should specify either of *sceneFit* or *displayPosition*.
If both properties are *not* specified the *sceneFit* will be set to `'contain'`.
See [Picimo.enum.ObjectFit](#) for more information.

attributes.name: displayPosition
attributes.description:
The *displayPosition* property has precedence over the *sceneFit* property.
When specified the *sceneFit* property will be ignored.

attributes.name: sizeFit
attributes.description:
The size fit option describes how the scene dimension is computed
in relation to the scene container.

attributes.description: The max sprite count.

attributes.name: sprites
attributes.description:
The vertex object descriptor name.

A sprite group expects that a sprite instance (created by the vertex object descriptor)
has the following properties:

| Type | Definition | Required | Comment |
|------|------------|----------|---------|
| Method | `setTexCoords(x0, y0, x1, y1, x2, y2, x3, y3)` | yes | |
| Method | `setSize(w, h)` | yes | _px_ |
| Method | `setScale(sx, sy)` | no | Either this or `scale=` |
| Property | `scale=` | no | Either this or `setScale(..)` |
| Property | `opacity=` | no | _[0..1]_ |

attributes.name: defaultHeight
attributes.description: The default sprite height.

dictionaries.name: Picimo.struct.DisplayPosition
dictionaries.description:
The display position specifies how the picture is positioned *in relationship to the scene dimension*.

Most properties will support a *string* as input. That means you can choose between different units:

| Type | Format | Unit | Description |
|------|------------|----------|---------|
| number | _any number_ | __px__ | pixel |
| string | `32px` | __px__ | pixel |
| string | `100iw` | __iw__ | image width percentage |
| string | `50.0ih` | __ih__ | image height percentage |
| string | `-80sw` | __sw__ | scene width percentage |
| string | `-1.1sh` | __sh__ | scene height percentage |
| string | `100 %` | __%__ | _see property description for the unit_ |

![The Display Position](/assets/images/doc/displayPosition.png)
![The Display Position Zoom](/assets/images/doc/displayPosition zoom.png)

attributes.name: top
attributes.description:
Set the top edge of the image under the top edge of the parent scene.

The unit is either of **px** (if value is a *number*) or of **percantage _of scene height_** (if value is a *string* — eg. `'50%'`)

attributes.name: left
attributes.description:
Set the left edge of the image right to the left edge of the parent scene.

The unit is either of **px** (if value is a *number*) or of **percantage _of scene width_** (if value is a *string* — eg. `'50%'`)

attributes.name: bottom
attributes.description:
Set the bottom edge of the image above the bottom edge of the parent scene.

The unit is either of **px** (if value is a *number*) or of **percantage _of scene height_** (if value is a *string* — eg. `'50%'`)

attributes.name: right
attributes.description:
Set the right edge of the image left to the right edge of the parent scene.

The unit is either of **px** (if value is a *number*) or of **percantage _of scene width_** (if value is a *string* — eg. `'50%'`)

attributes.name: width
attributes.description:
Set the width of the image.

The unit is either of **px** (if value is a *number*) or of **percantage _of image width_** (if value is a *string* — eg. `'50%'`)

attributes.name: height
attributes.description:
Set the height of the image.

The unit is either of **px** (if value is a *number*) or of **percantage _of image height_** (if value is a *string* — eg. `'50%'`)

attributes.name: zoom
attributes.description:
Set the zoom factor.

Default is `1.0` (no zoom). If set to `2.0` the size of the image will be _doubled_.

bootstrapping.title: Bootstrapping
bootstrapping.name: bootstrapping
bootstrapping.html:
You instantiate a picimo application by explicitly creating a new Picimo.App instance.

Simple Example

Assuming this index.html:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>a picimo application!</title>
    <style>
        html, body { height: 100%; }
        body { margin: 0; padding: 0; }
    </style>
  </head>
  <body>
    <script src="picimo.min.js"></script>
    <script>
        /* your bootstrapping code here */
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

We can use this minimal picimo application bootstrapping code:

var app = new Picimo.App({ alpha: false, bgColor: '#a0c0e0' });

// Set pixel resolution
app.scene.setSize(640, 480, 'contain');

When you instantiate the Picimo.App, picimo performs the following tasks:

  1. It creates a webgl <canvas> context (in this case without alpha support)
  2. It appends the <canvas> to the body as child (because you didn't specify the container element). This will create a fullscreen canvas, since you set the <body> (and <html>) height to 100%.
  3. It starts the main render loop and renders the scene (given that you didn't create some interesting scene graph nodes you will only see a blank blue scene here as result).

Congratulation! You created you first picimo application.

Now go on and create some more visual appealing stuff! Picimo offers some predefined scene graph nodes for you:
